___web_enable_cors.description: Enable CORS headers for the web interface. This is necessary for JS-clients accessing the server directly. If these are disabled, modern browsers will not be able to retrieve resources from the server

___web_endpoint_uri.description: Web interface endpoint URI. This setting can be overriden on a per-request basis with the X-Graylog-Server-URL header

___web_listen_uri.description: Web interface listen URI. It must not contain a path other than /

___web_thread_pool_size.description: The size of the thread pool used exclusively for serving the web interface

___web_max_header_size.description: The maximum size of the HTTP request headers in bytes

___web_enable.description: Enable the embedded Graylog web interface

___web_max_initial_line_length.description: The maximal length of the initial HTTP/1.1 line in bytes

___web_enable_gzip.description: Enable/disable GZIP support for the web interface. This compresses HTTP responses and therefore helps to reduce overall round trip times

___threads_allowed_to_block_multiplier.description: Number of threads allowed to be blocked by MongoDB connections multiplier

___max_connections.description: Increase this value according to the maximum connections your MongoDB server can handle from a single client if you encounter MongoDB connection problems

___root_email.description: The email address of the root user

___root_password_is_sha.description: Enable this if your root_password is a sha code

___root_password.description: Plain password for the admin user or a secure sha code

___password_secret.description: Set a secret to secure/pepper the stored user passwords

___node_id_file.description: The auto-generated node ID will be stored in this file and read after restarts. It is a good idea to use an absolute file path here if you are starting Graylog server from init scripts or similar

___root_timezone.description: The time zone setting of the root user. See http://www.joda.org/joda-time/timezones.html for a list of valid time zones

___is_master.description: If you are running more than one instances of Graylog server you have to select one of these instances as master. The master will perform some periodical tasks that non-masters won't perform

___content_packs_loader_enabled.description: Automatically load content packs in content_packs_dir on the first start of Graylog

___content_packs_uri.description: Valid URI to content-pack zip. The unzipped folder must contain the name of the last path of content_packs_dir e.g. content_pack

___content_packs_dir.description: The directory which contains content packs which should be loaded on the first start of Graylog

___content_packs_auto_load.description: A comma-separated list of content packs (files in content_packs_dir) which should be applied on the first start of Graylog e.g. grok-patterns.json

___analyzer.description: Analyzer (tokenizer) to use for message and full_message field. The standard filter usually is a good idea

___max_number_of_indices.description: How many indices do you want to keep?

___index_prefix.description: Prefix for all Elasticsearch indices and index aliases managed by Graylog

___retention_strategy.description: Graylog will use multiple indices to store documents in. You can configured the strategy it uses to determine when to rotate the currently active write index

___discovery_zen_ping_unicast_hosts.description: Elasticsearch nodes which Graylog is using to connect to the Elasticsearch cluster

___replicas.description: How many Elasticsearch replicas should be used per index? Note that this only applies to newly created indices

___max_docs_per_index.description: Maximum number of documents in an Elasticsearch index before a new index is being created, also see no_retention and elasticsearch_max_number_of_indices

___shards.description: How many Elasticsearch shards should be used per index? Note that this only applies to newly created indices

___plugin_uri.description: Valid URI to plugin zip. The unzipped folder must contain the name of the last path of plugin_dir e.g. plugin

___plugin_dir.description: Set plugin directory here (relative or absolute)

___heap_max.description: Memory (MB) max size for the JVM heap. This number should be less than the memory allocated to the Marathon instance (General rule: 50%)

___metaspace_max.description: Memory (MB) max size for the JVM Metaspace. This limit the amount of native memory used for class metadata

___heap_min.description: Memory (MB) start size for the JVM heap. This number should be be less or equals than the heap_max

___mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each Graylog task

___elasticsearch_transport_port.description: Port of the Elascticsearch client transport port

___instances.description: Number of Graylog instances to run

___host_volume.description: The location of a volume on the host to be used for enabled disk based message journal. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/graylog`). Note that this path must be the same on all DCOS agents

___role.description: Deploy Graylog only on nodes with this role

___disk.description: Disk (MB) to allocate to each Graylog instance

___cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each Graylog instance

___rest_thread_pool_size.description: The size of the thread pool used exclusively for serving the REST API

___rest_enable_gzip.description: Enable GZIP support for REST API. This compresses API responses and therefore helps to reduce overall round trip times. This is disabled by default. Uncomment the next line to enable it

___rest_max_header_size.description: The maximum size of the HTTP request headers in bytes

___rest_max_initial_line_length.description: The maximal length of the initial HTTP/1.1 line in bytes

___rest_listen_uri.description: REST API listen URI. Must be reachable by other Graylog server nodes if you run a cluster. When using Graylog Collectors, this URI will be used to receive heartbeat messages and must be accessible for all collectors

___rest_enable_cors.description: Enable CORS headers for REST API. This is necessary for JS-clients accessing the server directly. If these are disabled, modern browsers will not be able to retrieve resources from the server. This is enabled by default. Uncomment the next line to disable it

___rest_transport_uri.description: REST API transport address. Defaults to the value of rest_listen_uri. Exception: If rest_listen_uri is set to a wildcard IP address (0.0.0.0) the first non-loopback IPv4 system address is used. If set, this will be promoted in the cluster discovery APIs, so other nodes may try to connect on this address and it is used to generate URLs addressing entities in the REST API. (see rest_listen_uri). You will need to define this, if your Graylog server is running behind a HTTP proxy that is rewriting the scheme, host name or URI
